title: RL33386
content: The report provides an overview of federal civil rights statutes, highlighting the Civil Rights Act of 1964 as a significant legislation that expanded protections against discrimination. The statutes vary in the type of discrimination they address and the circumstances they cover. The report does not delve into additional civil rights protections under state or local laws. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 expanded protections against discrimination in employment, including Title VII which prohibits discrimination based on race, color, religion, national origin, or sex. The Pregnancy Discrimination Act prohibits discrimination based on pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions. Complaints of employment discrimination must be filed with the EEOC for private employers and the DOJ enforces Title VII against state and local governments. Title VI of the Civil Rights Act prohibits discrimination in federally funded programs based on race, color, or national origin. Complaints can be filed with the funding agency or in federal court. Title II prohibits discrimination in public accommodations based on race, color, religion, or national origin, enforced by the DOJ. The DOJ enforces Title II, which prohibits discrimination in public accommodations based on race, color, religion, or national origin. For more information on the CRA, refer to various CRS reports on affirmative action laws and legal developments. The curr_chunk discusses various CRS reports on legal issues such as sex discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual orientation discrimination, attorneys' fees, religion in the workplace, English as the official language, and employment discrimination and retaliation. The curr_chunk provides information on the Equal Pay Act, which prohibits sex-based discrimination in compensation, enforced by the EEOC. Pay discrimination claims can also be made under Title VII of the CRA. For more details, refer to CRS reports on pay equity legislation and the gender wage gap. The Voting Rights Act, enacted to prevent disenfranchisement of black voters, prohibits discriminatory voting practices based on race, color, or language minority status. DOJ enforces the act, allowing individuals to also sue in federal court. For more information, refer to CRS reports on congressional redistricting and the Voting Rights Act. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) prohibits age-based discrimination in employment for individuals aged 40 or older, enforced by the EEOC. It applies to employers with 20 or more employees. For more details, refer to CRS reports on the ADEA and related legal analyses. The Fair Housing Act (FHA) prohibits housing discrimination based on various factors such as race, color, religion, national origin, sex, disability, or familial status. It applies to both public and private housing and can be enforced by the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). The Fair Housing Act (FHA) prohibits discrimination in housing based on factors like race, color, religion, national origin, sex, disability, or familial status. It applies to public and private housing and can be enforced by HUD, DOJ, and individuals through federal court. Title IX prohibits sex discrimination in federally funded education programs, including intercollegiate athletics. Victims of discrimination can file complaints with the federal agency providing education funds. Title IX prohibits sex discrimination in federally funded education programs, and victims can file complaints with the federal agency providing education funds or file a lawsuit in federal court. DOJ coordinates federal Title IX activities, and additional information can be found in various CRS reports. The Rehabilitation Act prohibits disability discrimination in federally conducted and funded programs and employment. The Rehabilitation Act prohibits disability discrimination in federally conducted and funded programs and employment, with grant programs supporting vocational rehabilitation services. DOJ administers discrimination provisions in federally funded programs, while EEOC and DOL enforce nondiscrimination in federal employment and by federal contractors. The Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) prohibits discrimination in credit applications based on various factors. DOJ enforces the statute, and individuals can file complaints with overseeing agencies or sue in federal court. For more information on ECOA, refer to CRS Report RL30889 and CRS Report RS20430. The Equal Educational Opportunities Act (EEOA) prohibits discrimination in educational opportunities based on race, color, sex, or national origin, including school segregation and language barriers. It is enforced by the DOJ. The Age Discrimination Act prohibits age discrimination in federally funded programs. Victims can file complaints with the relevant federal agency. For more information on EEOA, refer to CRS Report RS22544. The Age Discrimination Act allows victims of discrimination to file complaints with the federal agency providing education funds or file a lawsuit in federal court. The Civil Service Reform Act prohibits discrimination in federal employment based on various factors and certain personnel practices. The Civil Service Reform Act (CSRA) prohibits discrimination in federal employment based on various factors, including sexual orientation. The Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) prohibits discrimination based on national origin or citizenship status in employment. The INA also protects individuals from unfair documentary practices related to employment eligibility verification. The CSRA is enforced by the Office of Special Counsel and the Merit Systems Protection Board, while the INA is enforced by the Department of Justice. The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) prohibits discrimination based on disability in various areas such as employment, public services, accommodations, transportation, and telecommunications. Enforcement is done by different agencies like the EEOC and DOJ, with the option for individuals to sue in federal court after filing a complaint. More information can be found on the CRS website and in specific reports on ADA issues and cases. The Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 (USERRA) prohibits employment discrimination against military servicemembers, enforced by the Department of Labor (DOL). The Congressional Accountability Act (CAA) applies civil rights laws to federal legislative branch employees. The Congressional Accountability Act (CAA) applies civil rights laws, including Title VII of the CRA, the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, and the Rehabilitation Act, to the legislative branch. The act is enforced by the Office of Compliance and includes provisions related to the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA) enforced by the Secretary of Health and Human Services for health insurers and employers. The Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act of 2008 (GINA) was enacted to protect individuals from genetic discrimination in employment and healthcare. It is enforced by the Secretary of Health and Human Services for health insurers and employers. Section 1981 of the U.S. Code prohibits discrimination in contractual relationships based on race, color, or citizenship, extending to employment relationships. It does not cover discrimination based on sex, religion, or national origin. Under 42 U.S.C. Section 1982, all U.S. citizens have the same property rights as white citizens, specifically in transactions involving real or personal property. Section 1982 prohibits intentional discrimination based on race. Section 1983 provides relief for deprivation of rights under state law but does not create new substantive rights. It is typically used to enforce constitutional rights. Section 1983 is commonly used to enforce constitutional rights, like equal protection, against public actors for intentional discrimination based on factors like race, sex, religion, or citizenship. Section 1985 addresses conspiracy to interfere with civil rights, allowing injured parties to recover damages from conspirators, but it's unclear if it covers discrimination beyond race.
